Line 151:  WriteLiteral(@"
Line 152:  </p>
Line 153:  <p>
Line 154:      This is quick and easy to add to your code. But once there, your console loggers get hard to manage because each
Line 155:      logger has to be updated on its own. And when you go live, you have to remember to modify your code to remove
Line 156:      all console loggers.
Line 157:  </p>
Line 158:  <p>
Line 159:      You can achieve the same benefits with JSNLog JavaScript loggers, without the drawbacks. Here is how.
Line 160:  </p>
Line 161:  
Line 162:  <h2>Log to the console instead of to the server</h2>
Line 163:  <p>
Line 164:      You can send log messages from your JavaScript loggers to the console instead of the server, using JSNLog's
Line 165:  ");

Line 187:  
Line 188:  WriteLiteral(@"<text>.</text>
Line 189:      To make that happen, modify the debug version of your web.config:
Line 190:  </p>
Line 191:  <pre><!-- Debug version of web.config -->
Line 192:  <jsnlog>
Line 193:      <!-- Create console appender -->
Line 194:      <consoleAppender name=""consoleAppender"" /><br />
Line 195:      <!-- Send all log messages to console appender -->
Line 196:      <logger appenders=""consoleAppender"" />
Line 197:  </jsnlog></pre>
Line 198:  <p>
Line 199:      Then replace your console logs with JavaScript loggers:
Line 200:  </p>
Line 201:  <pre>
Line 202:  <strike>console.log('debug message');</strike>
Line 203:  JL().debug('debug message');
Line 204:  </pre>
Line 205:  
Line 206:  <h2>Guaranteeing no live console loggers in live site</h2>
Line 207:  
Line 208:  <p>
Line 209:      To ensure your console loggers are disabled in your live site,
Line 210:      make sure that the Release version of your web.config
Line 211:      stops all debug messages and that it doesn't create the console appender:
Line 212:  </p>
Line 213:  <pre><!-- Release version of web.config -->
Line 214:  <jsnlog>
Line 215:      <!-- Stop all message with severity lower than fatal -->
Line 216:      <logger level=""FATAL"" />
Line 217:  </jsnlog></pre>
Line 218:  <p>
Line 219:      That way, you and your team can be sure there will be no live console loggers in your live site.
Line 220:  </p>
Line 221:  
Line 222:  <p>
Line 223:      Just in case, it is easy to maintain Debug and Release versions of your web.config using
Line 224:      <a");
Line 225:
